results.title: Marco Solo
results.creator_credit: Adrian Bosich and VCA Film and Television School, University of Melbourne
results.brief_description:
Poor Marco. Accidentally born into an overcrowded Australian-Italian household, he is relegated to his parents’ bedroom. Nine years later, armed with a vivid imagination, an obsession with Dame Edna, and a warped sense of Catholicism, Marco searches for a space of his own. Cast includes Joseph Sollena, Robert Urban, Helen Nicholas, Irini Pappas, Maria Diele.
‘Marco Solo’ screened at many film festivals, including Palm Springs and London International Film Festival.

results.title: Marco Polo's travels
results.creator_credit: Hal Kopel and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description: Marco Polo wrote a book of his travels in 1298, when he was a POW. He was 17 when he left Venice on his journey. This film tells the story of Marco Polo’s travels to China and back to Europe. An animated map traces his historic journey.

results.title: Marcia is here
results.creator_credit: D. Keith Carlson and WGBH Educational Foundation
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The Kindergarten child series”.
To start the afternoon at kindergarten children here are encouraged to move about freely without adult intervention in the classroom in order to unwind and release tension. Some of the activities involve playing with hoops, bouncing balls, and hop-scotch. The teacher checks attendance by having the children select the letters of their name and form an appropriate sentence such as “Marica is here”. Freedom of activity is encouraged in the afternoon program.

results.title: Marching the colours
results.brief_description: An experiment in film animation, visualising a well-known military march in geometric, abstract patterns of colour. Bold hues move, march, blend and separate in a dynamic pattern of mobile forms, transporting into colour and shape the sound patterns of the accompanying music. This film made by Guy Glover, without use of a camera.

results.title: March of the wooden soldiers = Babes in Toyland
results.creator_credit: Hal Roach, Federal Films, Charles Rogers and Gus Meins
results.brief_description: Laurel and Hardy are well-meaning toymakers who muddle an order for Santa. Instead on making one 600 foot high soldier, they make one hundred six-foot soldiers instead. The toy army comes in handy when Barnaby and his furry Bogeymen invade Toyland. The boys end up as heroes as they save Widow Peep’s daughter Bo. Originally known as “Babes in Toyland”, the film was heavily censored as it was considered too scary for children, and it was seldom seen after the Disney remake of 1963. Nevertheless, it remained one of Laurel and Hardy’s best films and it was the personal favourite of Hardy.

results.title: Marcel Proust: from masterpieces to a master's work
results.creator_credit: C A P A C and Jacques Letellier
results.brief_description: Intended to deepen our appreciation and understanding of Proust’s works by reviewing some of the masterpieces of art and music which inspired him and led him to recognise his vocation as a writer. The effect of the Dreyfus case and the Great War are indicated and the lack of interest in his work during his lifetime.
results.title_for_label: Marcel Proust: from masterpieces to a master’s work

results.title: Marcel Duchamp: a game of chess
results.creator_credit: Jean-Marie Drot, RM Associates and INA France
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Phaidon art collection”.
Filmed in 1963 the program offers an in-depth dialogue between renowned artist Marcel Duchamp and film-maker Jean-Marie Drot over a game of chess and a tour of Duchamp’s first one man show at the Pasadena Art Museum in 1963. Duchamp details his life and work only 5 years before his death in a discussion of his time in the United States after fleeing France in 1915. The discussion touches on his view of the country in social and political terms as well as its impact on his own work, intermingled with visual contemplations on the progression of his artwork from painting to photographs throughout his career. Recognised for varying artistic practices which included brushes with Impressionism and Cubism, Duchamp is also largely known for his founding influence in Surrealism and Dada. Here he recounts the stages of his work with full colour shots of the relevant pieces evoking a detailed sense of the significance of these different times in his life personally, politically and most of all artistically. The game of chess which punctuates the dialogue, a passion for Duchamp throughout his career, acts as an insightful metaphor for the mental discipline he applies to his work and an avenue for its explanation and contemplation. Contains some scenes in b&w. In French with English subtitles.

results.title: Marcel
results.brief_description: Marcel stands aloft on a balcony as he watches 6 pallbearers carry an empty coffin; the pallbearers are coming for him. Cast includes John Bailey, Christopher Palmer, Johannes Davies, Davidson Wire, James Reg and William Frew.
results.description: Marcel stands aloft on a balcony as he watches 6 pallbearers carry an empty coffin; the pallbearers are coming for him. Cast includes John Bailey, Christopher Palmer, Johannes Davies, Davidson Wire, James Reg and William Frew.

results.title: Marceau on Mime
results.brief_description: Marcel Marceau, world famous French mime, talks about his life and work, about his theories on mime and the history of pantomime in the theatre. He traces mime through the Greek theatre, the commedia del’arte, the Pierrot of the 19th century and the comics of film, like Chaplin, Keaton, Lloyd, and Laurel and Hardy. Marceau started out to be a painter and still does drawings and paintings. He feels that mime is closely related to the graphic arts as well as to music and dance.
